segments.text: Well, I think the time I first started thinking about oceanography was before there was any really formal training, you might say, or curriculum or degrees in oceanography.

It wasn't until, oh, what, the last 20 years, something like that, that there is a formal training curriculum in oceanography, degree-granting, graduate degree-granting, and, of course, outfits like Scripps was one of the first ones.
As a matter of fact, right now, today, of the 10 leading, or 12, depends on how you want to argue it, leading oceanographic institutions in the country,
There's only one director who actually has a formal degree in oceanography, and that's Johnny Knauss up in Rhode Island.
All the other directors have come through it by not necessarily a circuitous route,

from the outside, so to speak, because I mentioned the lack of formal training in oceanography, to mouth anything until about 20 years ago, in one of the disciplines that comprise the sub-disciplines of oceanography.
Oceanography isn't a separate discipline like geology or chemistry or biology, but it's the use of all those to solve problems in the environment of the ocean.
And that's one reason why we don't have an undergraduate degree in oceanography.
And again, the leading oceanographic institution with one exception, the University of Washington, doesn't have an undergraduate degree.
Because you have to be first grounded in some basic science and certain peripheral subjects along with it before you can really begin to do a job professionally in oceanography.
So in my case, I came through the geologist geophysical route.
For example, Paul Fein out with Hall as a chemist, Nirenberg, Scripps as a physicist.
And right on down the line, Bradtray out at Washington is a, let's see, he's a chemist.
And John Byrne at Oregon State is a geologist.
George Bullard, who wrote a hat to Hawaii, is also a geophysicist.
So this is the way the situation basically exists.
And so in answer to your question, which may seem to be a long way around the mulberry bush, is that I came to oceanography through the virtue of geology and geophysics because

Once having applied this information on land, obviously, in order to solve some of the problems, you had to turn to the sea, particularly in such major areas as crustal evolution, drifting continents, and whatnot, and the origin of continents and ocean basins.
But the geologists on land can't solve these problems because the answers are skewed by thousands and, in some cases, tens of thousands of feet of sediment.

And if it weren't for the information of the geological and geophysical ocean arcs that had gotten at sea, we never would have had the information we have now toward solving the earlier problems I mentioned.
Well, when did these problems first occur to you?
Do you remember?
Was it when you were working at Standard, or was it prior to that?
No, these problems occurred to me actually when I was working for my graduate degree at Princeton, because my major professor there, Dr. Harry Hess,
had already started going to sea to start solving some of these problems using Vainik Mayonnaise's pendulums and a submarine and paddling around the Caribbean and whatnot.
And George Willard, who had just graduated from Princeton when I first came, and Maurice Ewing were making studies off the New Jersey coast in the water.
Did you participate in these?
No, I didn't participate.
No.
before I came doing this work.
And just by the time I came, he left and went up to withhold.
And so when the war came along, with all the
practical problems that were thrown in the laps of the oceanographers at Woods Hole to solve.

I was soon asked to join the staff, so I did most of my war work at Woods Hole in the oceanographic factors affecting sound ranging in the sea, the Navy problems, anti-submarine, pro-submarine warfare.
So that's how I wound up at Woods Hole.
Now, you were an instructor at Princeton from 38 to 42.
This overlaps with private business, it seemed to me.
You were also listed at Standard Oil at the same time.
Is that correct?
Well, I was a consultant at Standard Oil at that time.
What happened was I worked for Standard Oil in New Jersey and New York before I went to Princeton.
And then I decided to go on and get my PhD.
And so they supported me with consulting work part of the time, although I was on a fellowship at Princeton.
So I can see where the question arises.
42, you go to the Navy.
Right.
And then most of your work you do for the Navy is done at Woods Hole.
Yeah.

Although I did start out doing some work for the Navy in Rhode Island in connection with the gousing ships, which is also geophysics, protecting the ships from magnetic mines that were planted in the water.
by wrapping coils of copper around the ship and putting current through it to set up a field equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to that of the ship's field.
So when the ship went over a magnetic mine, the mine, there was no magnetic field force in the ship
trigger and set off the mine, or the triggering mechanism.
And that problem was solved pretty rapidly, and it went from there to Woods Hole on the submarine work.
Does that explain, then, your interest in magnetism?
Yeah.
Did you come to that as a petroleum engineer, or was this... Geophysical.
Geophysical.
Okay.
And then you were asked to apply that then in the Navy, a specific problem you were assigned to solve in the Navy.
Okay.
So you were involved in the anti-submarine work?
Yeah, at Woods Hole and in the, you might say, geomagnetism the first couple years at Rhode Island.
Did you meet Spilhaus involving the anti-submarine work?
No, I didn't meet Spilhaus until, oh golly, about 1948 or 49.
Spillhouse had left Woods Hole at the time when I came in.
It was about 41, I think.
When you leave the Navy in 45 and then return to Woods Hole?
No, chronologically, as I recall, I left the Navy in 42 and went to Woods Hole in 42 to 45.
And then at the end of 45, I went back to work for Standard & Jersey and won the subsidiaries, in this case Humboldt.
What sort of work was going on at Woods Hole between 1942 and 1945?
Was it primarily work involving the war effort?
Yeah, not only in connection with anti-submarine, pro-submarine warfare, but for
underwater photography, looking for wrecks and sunken enemy submarines to get a better idea of what they looked like.
And then depth charges, more chemistry and more efficient ways of using depth charges.
There was a whole gamut of things.
More passive things is developing anti-fouling paints so that the ships wouldn't have to be painted as often and could go through the water fast.
Oh, just a jillion things.
But they were, as you say, all directed toward pragmatic war problems that needed to be solved.
Actually, before the war, Woods Hole did not operate all year round.
They just had funds to operate in the summertime.
And it wasn't until the war came along that they got funding from the Navy and the Army and the Air Force and whatnot that they operated on 12-month days.
Did Woods Hole always have some sort of a contact with the Ivy League?
We're struck more often than not how many people are brought in from the geophysics and from various places to work at Woods Hole as senior researchers, so to speak.
Of course, there again, the geographical position tend toward that direction.
And they were close to, say, the Ivy League.
And Harvard had a good representation, even in the days of summertime, of climate only.
And Columbus-Island was in Harvard on the faculty.
In fact, most of the people that were on the Harvard faculty, a lot of this spread out into Princeton and some of the other, the bulk of it was
One of the first directors, Bigelow, was a Harvard man, and then Islin was the second.
Actually, Woods Hole didn't become a degree-granting institution until about, well, more than the last ten years.
Did you sell any oceanographic vessels out of Woods Hole?
I read an article of yours where you suggested
or you describe the importance of these vessels.
Do you have any comments you'd like to make on these?
The Thompson?
I'm sailed on the Thompson.
No, no, not sailed on them.
I said that you made comments about how you thought these were innovations in oceanographic research.
This is a two-way street.
I'm minding something.
The Thompson is a relatively new agar-type vessel that's been floating around now for about 89 years.
And it isn't particularly innovative.
Well, what would be its exact job?
You say that these vessels are probably now designed to do specialized work in oceanography rather than general work, I suppose, in comparison with the Challenger and the type of mission.
Yeah, no.
The Thompson is doing pretty much the same as the Challenger.
It belongs to the Navy, but it's on bailment to Scripps.
It's one of an Agor class, the Thompson and Scripps, and we've got a similar one up in the University of Washington.
That's not the Washington itself, is it?
No, it's the other way around.
It's very confusing.
Two Agors, the names of them.
One is named, you'd think it's Washington, but it belongs to Scripps, and the Thompson belongs to...
University of Washington.
But anyway, those are minor points.
I don't remember saying anything about the Thompson or the Washington or the Agos in general.
I did write an article once in connection with the new type of vessels that the Navy has now, the Gyre and the
Moana Wave out of Hawaii, which were an outgrowth of a special type of vessel that we designed when I was a TI to do work at sea in the Navy.
I think that's what it is.
This one over here is one of the parts in this class that we designed at Texas Instruments and used for contract work with the Navy and with the
oil companies and whatnot.
That's what I'm trying to lead into, actually, is while at TI, which is jumping ahead of our story, what sort of innovations did you work in in oceanography at TI?
Well, for one thing, the design of a vessel that gave more flexibility to a particular type of mission as a function of its length.
In other words, what we have now in the gyre, we have a series of vans of different
that are designed for particular sub-disciplines of oceanography, like chemical oceanography, and theological, and physical, and so on.

And so by having a lot of after-deck on a ship available to put these specialized vans on, you can get more laboratory space for a particular mission of some certain type than you could if you tried to have the same lab space for the four disciplines on one ship.
It would be like the French then.
I think that's one of the things we worked on, along with Captain Rowe, when I was a TI.
Hank Rowe, who was a retired captain of the Navy, worked with me very closely.
In fact, when I came here and the Navy decided to build the type of vessel we have now, the Jarrah type, that he continued his work with them and with ourselves as a consultant on it.
So Hank Rowe is the one who really worked out the details and made it gritty with this new type of vessel.
Would you explain exactly how it would work?
I take it you put compartments on for... Yeah, the ship has basic laboratory space that's used by all the disciplines, like electronics lab.
for electronic information and navigation and so on.
Then a wet lab.
But then, from there on out, it's just a steel deck, except for winches and things like that.
And if a cruise, the emphasis is supposed to be on chemical oceanography, well, then the van-type labs that you put on board are all outfitted, especially for chemistry, if it's biology, for biology.
And that way, you can get more for your money, so to speak, on this particular type of...
mission than if you just had a ship that had cubby holes for this branch and that branch.
Of course, it doesn't have to be restricted entirely to one sub-discipline.
You have two sub-disciplines.
What was your role in this design?
Was it more as a researcher who would know what kinds of things you would need, giving ideas as to what
compartments you might want and leaving it up to them to design how it was going to be?
Exactly, yeah.
I mean, I make no pretense of being a naval architect or anything.
The ship design and whatnot was left to that type of person, but I think you put it pretty well as to what my role was in it.
The advantages of this type of flexibility.
So from experience, you were telling them what you needed and then let them work out the detail of how it was put together.
Right.
For example, I never thought of increasing the freeboard 18 inches by putting gratings over the main deck, putting a false deck over it, which achieved the advantage of giving you more freeboard.
And yet at the same time, you could also run cables and piping connections without tripping over them.
I mean, things like that Roe thought of, I think.
What's a freeboard?
That's the distance from the deck to the water line.
And that's another advantage of this type of ship as compared, say, to the Russian ships.
They have such a high free port.
It's more luxurious in the standpoint of having more room for recreation and whatnot.
It doesn't roll as much.
You can be away from port longer.
But they take things that look like a cruise ship on their oceanographic vessels.
And so you're standing 40 or 50 feet or more above the water trying to handle equipment and instruments and whatnot.
On the other hand, if you've been in the sea on a gyre, you'll have the same complaint that other people have, which is you get your feet wet all the time.
There's no happy medium between the two.
Well, that's something that Spilhaus, I believe, said was important for an oceanographer.
Yeah.
To do at least several times.
I wonder whether he meant it literally or briefly.
Did you spend much time on these oceanographic vessels while you were at TI or before?
Yeah, in order to only test out these ideas that we had, but more or less in a supervisory capacity.
What vessels did you sail on in particular?
Well, the Atlantic seal and the Arctic seal.
the ones I spent most of the time on.
Is there any description you'd like to make of the cruises?
Not really.

I mean, they're a regular routine type of oceanographic cruises whose mission varied from gathering geological and geophysical sub-bottom information to, in the case of some of the Navy work, was classified.
Can't talk about that too much, although some of the Navy work wasn't classified.
to gain information about the sea and beneath the sea.
Again, to solve specific problems.
Ed, we have you at a geophysicist at Humble Oil between 45 and 48.
And what we'd like to know are two things involving that.
First of all, were you involved in development of seaward planning for ESSO?
Yeah, in two ways.
One, in connection with the amount of area offshore that might lend itself to potential oil problems.
And then some of the problems that you would get into in connection with getting oil from and producing oil from once you found the oil and dealing with problems.
But there again, it is a question of bouncing back and forth.

I started out in geology and geophysics at Princeton, and then I applied those principles to acoustics to solving problems with Woods Hole in connection with the war, and then, of course, the first part in connection with magnetic mines.
And then oceanography.
Frankly, there was no market for oceanographers, per se, at that time.
So I fell back on my original training in geology and geophysics and went back to work for Humble, first as a research geophysicist.

And then when they started getting interested in going to the Gulf area and getting their feet wet, as Spilly would say, they looked around for someone who knew something about oceanography, and Humble being a pretty big company,
didn't realize they had the closest thing in oceanography at that time already within their group.
And so they went to Woods Hole to try to hire somebody, and Woods Hole told them, well, they had a pretty good oceanographer right on their staff.
So then he came to me and asked me to set up an oceanographic section, which is that next period there.
Which is 1945, 49 to 54.
Yeah.
Right.
Well, we noticed that in 1949 and 1950, you presented both your first paper and began to publish.
Does that explain...
Your upward mobility, or is it in terms of Humboldt?
Yeah.
I think the first thing I did for Humboldt, I mean, one of the first things I did for Humboldt that was published was that bibliography of marine geology and geophysics.
I went back to Woods Hole for a summer and spent the whole summer in the library putting it together.
And then we also figured out from management to say that
what the problems were going offshore in the provinces, potential provinces, and where the potential provinces were.

And then to take the geophysical instruments that have been developed for land work, like the gravimeter and magnetometer, and adapt them to making observations at sea under continuous activity, I mean, in continuous motion.
and not only a standard gravity meter and magnetics, but also electrical methods for looking for salt domes.
I guess I happen to have pictures here of the early Humboldt fleet.

a boat converted to making surveys using an electromagnetic field of the Earth to find the salt dome because of the big difference in electromagnetic characteristics between the salt dome and the surrounding sediments.
So it's just a question of applying
basic principles of geology and geophysics to marine modifications who are necessary in order to operate in a marine environment.
These are some of the early Humboldt ships, as you probably recognize them.
They're straight subchases that were used during the Navy for
anti-submarine warfare work.
And then there was surplus when the war was over.
And those were the first things that the oil companies and the service companies latched on to buy.
And here's one you can see.
Gravity meter on the thing.
Great big old bulky thing that was put over the side of the ship.
and lower down to the bottom to make a reading.
When I first came with Humble, they actually had a diving bell that they put this poor guy in with a gravity meter and then clamped the top on and lowered him over the side of the ship.
Well, it wasn't a ship, in this case, a subchaser.
And of course, if the sea were running at all, any sort of waves, well, he was very reluctant to go down and make a gravity measurement.
And I noticed there was never any argument between the supervisor and the guy, because the instrument man would probably say, well, if you think it's so hot, well, you go down yourself.

This is a very crude way of first starting out, taking an actual meter that was designed for making observations on land, putting it in the lap of a guy and putting him in a tin can, putting it on down, putting him on the bottom.
Then the next step was the one that you see on here, where they designed a gravity meter that could be read remotely on the bottom.

And finally, today, the evolutionary history of it is where you have gravity meters that are put on ships, and instead of making observations point to point the way the man and the bell would be, or the
that type of gravity meter on that ship there.
We can get a readout on the ship chart as we go along.
Was Humble one of the first companies to start heading for the sea and doing this research?
Yeah, Humble and Mobile were probably the first.
Actually, Mobile was the first one.
If the truth were known, and at this point it's no longer classified, none of the companies want to go to sea because they didn't have any experience in it and whatnot.
But once one company went to sea, well, the self-preservation, all the others had to do too for fear that this one company would get to jump on all the goodies out there.
So one group after another went to sea.
But Humble was the first company to have actually designated an oceanographer and an oceanographic section.
Shell was the second one.
And then a lot of the others just contracted their work out to consulting companies that needed oceanographic work.
Well, once the exploration phase and transition was made, it turned out that Humboldt felt that probably I could do more good in the production, producing activities.

And in other words, what sort of wave forces would act upon these offshore platforms that they were going to stick in the water to drill off and produce from, if they hadn't had any experience before.
and problems of following organisms on the platform.
So it was a whole new area.
And that's when I first got involved with Professor Reed.

I was chairman of an API committee, American Petroleum Institute Committee, on getting together from the oil companies their design criteria for offshore platforms with regard to wave forces on them and whatnot.
He participated in that symposium that we had at that time.
Now, when was this?
That was about the middle 50s.
About the middle 50s, while you were still director of the oceanography section?
Yeah.
One of the things that really slowed it up was the Truman proclamation and the leasing restrictions that he put on.
The company didn't know whether their leases would be valid or not, so they held off for a while.
oceanography, you might say commercial oceanography in the oil company, so it leveled off for a while.

And so that's why I left in 54 to go with Geophysical Service, Inc., which is the originator of Texas Instruments, because they offered me a job in heading up their new gravity and magnetic divisions, and that's
I could see myself at the time when I left the Humboldt.
It was just being plateauing for a while.
This looked like a new opportunity to me, a lot of fun.
So I went back to that field, although, again, I was still doing work for GSI at sea, the way I had been doing for Humboldt, only this time, again, the exploration side.
People, not people, but a number, several people have said I'm a charlatan or a genius, one or the other.
And I protest rigorously on neither.

This precipitated by the time, again, I was with TI in the early 60s when I had a contract with NASA to figure out what geological and geophysical experiments should be made when the astronauts arrived on the moon.
And the first guy that called me, Charlton, was one of the competitors that also had a proposal and didn't get the contract.
And he said, what do you mean?
He said, you start out as a land geologist and geophysicist, and then you turn into an oceanographer and go to sea.
And now you're telling people what should be done on the moon in geology and geophysics.
And I said, well, it's simple, because the fundamentals of geology and geophysics are the same, whether you happen to be on planet Earth or on planet water or on planet moon.
Simple as that.
And it was interesting to see that.
See, that was in around the early 60s, when the astronauts did land on the moon, that they followed out pretty well the things that
Jacqueline Lopek and myself had outlined, with the help, of course, of about 25 consultants, what should be done.
We also looked for water on the moon, too.
This group that I was involved in and running at the time.
That's even more solemn than we all know.
There's very little water on the moon.
A lot of people had ideas that perhaps there'd be some sort of a...
Oh, hydrate just below the meteoric dust.
All right, this explains, then, your interest in space in the mid-1960s.
Yeah.
